0.speaker: BROKAW:
0.text: Good evening from Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee. I'm Tom Brokaw of NBC News. And welcome to this second presidential debate, sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.
0.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

1.speaker: BROKAW:
1.text: Tonight's debate is the only one with a town hall format. The Gallup Organization chose 80 uncommitted voters from the Nashville area to be here with us tonight. And earlier today, each of them gave me a copy of their question for the candidates.
1.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

2.speaker: BROKAW:
2.text: From all of these questions -- and from tens of thousands submitted online -- I have selected a long list of excellent questions on domestic and foreign policy.
2.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

3.speaker: BROKAW:
3.text: Neither the commission nor the candidates have seen the questions. And although we won't be able to get to all of them tonight, we should have a wide-ranging discussion one month before the election.
3.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

4.speaker: BROKAW:
4.text: Each candidate will have two minutes to respond to a common question, and there will be a one-minute follow-up. The audience here in the hall has agreed to be polite, and attentive, no cheering or outbursts. Those of you at home, of course, are not so constrained.
4.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

5.speaker: BROKAW:
5.text: The only exception in the hall is right now, as it is my privilege to introduce the candidates, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois and Senator John McCain of Arizona.
5.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

6.speaker: BROKAW:
6.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

7.speaker: BROKAW:
7.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

8.speaker: BROKAW:
8.text: Gentlemen, we want to get underway immediately, if we can. Since you last met at Ole Miss 12 days ago, the world has changed a great deal, and not for the better. We still don't know where the bottom is at this time.
8.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

9.speaker: BROKAW:
9.text: As you might expect, many of the questions that we have from here in the hall tonight and from online have to do with the American economy and, in fact, with global economic conditions.
9.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

10.speaker: BROKAW:
10.text: I understand that you flipped a coin.
10.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

11.speaker: BROKAW:
11.text: And, Senator Obama, you will begin tonight. And we're going to have our first question from over here in Section A from Alan Schaefer.
11.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

12.speaker: BROKAW:
12.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

13.speaker: QUESTION:
13.text: With the economy on the downturn and retired and older citizens and workers losing their incomes, what's the fastest, most positive solution to bail these people out of the economic ruin?
13.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

14.speaker: OBAMA:
14.text: Well, Alan, thank you very much for the question. I want to first, obviously, thank Belmont University, Tom, thank you, and to all of you who are participating tonight and those of you who sent e-mail questions in.
14.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

15.speaker: OBAMA:
15.text: I think everybody knows now we are in the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And a lot of you I think are worried about your jobs, your pensions, your retirement accounts, your ability to send your child or your grandchild to college.
15.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

16.speaker: OBAMA:
16.text: And I believe this is a final verdict on the failed economic policies of the last eight years, strongly promoted by President Bush and supported by Senator McCain, that essentially said that we should strip away regulations, consumer protections, let the market run wild, and prosperity would rain down on all of us.
16.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

17.speaker: OBAMA:
17.text: It hasn't worked out that way. And so now we've got to take some decisive action.
17.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

18.speaker: OBAMA:
18.text: Now, step one was a rescue package that was passed last week. We've got to make sure that works properly. And that means strong oversight, making sure that investors, taxpayers are getting their money back and treated as investors.
18.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

19.speaker: OBAMA:
19.text: It means that we are cracking down on CEOs and making sure that they're not getting bonuses or golden parachutes as a consequence of this package. And, in fact, we just found out that AIG, a company that got a bailout, just a week after they got help went on a $400,000 junket.
19.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

20.speaker: OBAMA:
20.text: And I'll tell you what, the Treasury should demand that money back and those executives should be fired. But that's only step one. The middle-class need a rescue package. And that means tax cuts for the middle-class.
20.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

21.speaker: OBAMA:
21.text: It means help for homeowners so that they can stay in their homes. It means that we are helping state and local governments set up road projects and bridge projects that keep people in their jobs.
21.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

22.speaker: OBAMA:
22.text: And then long-term we've got to fix our health care system, we've got to fix our energy system that is putting such an enormous burden on families. You need somebody working for you and you've got to have somebody in Washington who is thinking about the middle class and not just those who can afford to hire lobbyists.
22.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

23.speaker: BROKAW:
23.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

24.speaker: MCCAIN:
24.text: Well, thank you, Tom. Thank you, Belmont University. And Senator Obama, it's good to be with you at a town hall meeting.
24.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

25.speaker: MCCAIN:
25.text: And, Alan, thank you for your question. You go to the heart of America's worries tonight. Americans are angry, they're upset, and they're a little fearful. It's our job to fix the problem.
25.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

26.speaker: MCCAIN:
26.text: Now, I have a plan to fix this problem and it has got to do with energy independence. We've got to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't want us very -- like us very much. We have to keep Americans' taxes low. All Americans' taxes low. Let's not raise taxes on anybody today.
26.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

27.speaker: MCCAIN:
27.text: We obviously have to stop this spending spree that's going on in Washington. Do you know that we've laid a $10 trillion debt on these young Americans who are here with us tonight, $500 billion of it we owe to China? We've got to have a package of reforms and it has got to lead to reform prosperity and peace in the world. And I think that this problem has become so severe, as you know, that we're going to have to do something about home values.
27.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

28.speaker: MCCAIN:
28.text: You know that home values of retirees continues to decline and people are no longer able to afford their mortgage payments. As president of the United States, Alan, I would order the secretary of the treasury to immediately buy up the bad home loan mortgages in America and renegotiate at the new value of those homes -- at the diminished value of those homes and let people be able to make those -- be able to make those payments and stay in their homes.
28.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

29.speaker: MCCAIN:
29.text: Is it expensive? Yes. But we all know, my friends, until we stabilize home values in America, we're never going to start turning around and creating jobs and fixing our economy. And we've got to give some trust and confidence back to America.
29.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

30.speaker: MCCAIN:
30.text: I know how the do that, my friends. And it's my proposal, it's not Senator Obama's proposal, it's not President Bush's proposal. But I know how to get America working again, restore our economy and take care of working Americans. Thank you.
30.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

31.speaker: BROKAW:
31.text: Senator, we have one minute for a discussion here. Obviously the powers of the treasury secretary have been greatly expanded. The most powerful officer in the cabinet now. Hank Paulson says he won't stay on. Who do you have in mind to appoint to that very important post?
31.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

32.speaker: BROKAW:
32.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

33.speaker: MCCAIN:
33.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

34.speaker: MCCAIN:
34.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

35.speaker: BROKAW:
35.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

36.speaker: MCCAIN:
36.text: You know, that's a tough question and there's a lot of qualified Americans. But I think the first criteria, Tom, would have to be somebody who immediately Americans identify with, immediately say, we can trust that individual.
36.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

37.speaker: MCCAIN:
37.text: A supporter of Senator Obama's is Warren Buffett. He has already weighed in and helped stabilize some of the difficulties in the markets and with companies and corporations, institutions today.
37.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

38.speaker: MCCAIN:
38.text: I like Meg Whitman, she knows what it's like to be out there in the marketplace. She knows how to create jobs. Meg Whitman was CEO of a company that started with 12 people and is now 1.3 million people in America make their living off eBay. Maybe somebody here has done a little business with them.
38.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

39.speaker: MCCAIN:
39.text: But the point is it's going to have to be somebody who inspires trust and confidence. Because the problem in America today to a large extent, Tom, is that we don't have trust and confidence in our institutions because of the corruption on Wall Street and the greed and excess and the cronyism in Washington, D.C.
39.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

40.speaker: BROKAW:
40.text: All right. Senator McCain -- Senator Obama, who do you have in mind for treasury secretary?
40.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

41.speaker: OBAMA:
41.text: Well, Warren would be a pretty good choice -- Warren Buffett, and I'm pleased to have his support. But there are other folks out there. The key is making sure that the next treasury secretary understands that it's not enough just to help those at the top.
41.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

42.speaker: OBAMA:
42.text: Prosperity is not just going to trickle down. We've got to help the middle class.
42.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

43.speaker: OBAMA:
43.text: And we've -- you know, Senator McCain and I have some fundamental disagreements on the economy, starting with Senator McCain's statement earlier that he thought the fundamentals of the economy were sound.
43.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

44.speaker: OBAMA:
44.text: Part of the problem here is that for many of you, wages and incomes have flat-lined. For many of you, it is getting harder and harder to save, harder and harder to retire.
44.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

45.speaker: OBAMA:
45.text: And that's why, for example, on tax policy, what I want to do is provide a middle class tax cut to 95 percent of working Americans, those who are working two jobs, people who are not spending enough time with their kids, because they are struggling to make ends meet.
45.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

46.speaker: OBAMA:
46.text: Senator McCain is right that we've got to stabilize housing prices. But underlying that is loss of jobs and loss of income. That's something that the next treasury secretary is going to have to work on.
46.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

47.speaker: BROKAW:
47.text: Senator Obama, thank you very much.
47.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

48.speaker: BROKAW:
48.text: May I remind both of you, if I can, that we're operating under rules that you signed off on and when we have a discussion, it really is to be confined within about a minute or so.
48.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

49.speaker: BROKAW:
49.text: We're going to go now, Senator McCain, to the next question from you from the hall here, and it comes from Oliver Clark, who is over here in section F.
49.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

50.speaker: BROKAW:
50.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

51.speaker: QUESTION:
51.text: Well, Senators, through this economic crisis, most of the people that I know have had a difficult time. And through this bailout package, I was wondering what it is that's going to actually help those people out.
51.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

52.speaker: MCCAIN:
52.text: Well, thank you, Oliver, and that's an excellent question, because as you just described it, bailout, when I believe that it's rescue, because -- because of the greed and excess in Washington and Wall Street, Main Street was paying a very heavy price, and we know that.
52.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

53.speaker: MCCAIN:
53.text: I left my campaign and suspended it to go back to Washington to make sure that there were additional protections for the taxpayer in the form of good oversight, in the form of taxpayers being the first to be paid back when our economy recovers -- and it will recover -- and a number of other measures.
53.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

54.speaker: MCCAIN:
54.text: But you know, one of the real catalysts, really the match that lit this fire was Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. I'll bet you, you may never even have heard of them before this crisis.
54.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

55.speaker: MCCAIN:
55.text: But you know, they're the ones that, with the encouragement of Senator Obama and his cronies and his friends in Washington, that went out and made all these risky loans, gave them to people that could never afford to pay back.
55.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

56.speaker: MCCAIN:
56.text: And you know, there were some of us that stood up two years ago and said we've got to enact legislation to fix this. We've got to stop this greed and excess.
56.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

57.speaker: MCCAIN:
57.text: Meanwhile, the Democrats in the Senate and some -- and some members of Congress defended what Fannie and Freddie were doing. They resisted any change.
57.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

58.speaker: MCCAIN:
58.text: Meanwhile, they were getting all kinds of money in campaign contributions. Senator Obama was the second highest recipient of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac money in history -- in history.
58.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

59.speaker: MCCAIN:
59.text: So this rescue package means that we will stabilize markets, we will shore up these institutions. But it's not enough. That's why we're going to have to go out into the housing market and we're going to have to buy up these bad loans and we're going to have to stabilize home values, and that way, Americans, like Alan, can realize the American dream and stay in their home.
59.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

60.speaker: MCCAIN:
60.text: But Fannie and Freddie were the catalysts, the match that started this forest fire. There were some of us -- there were some of us that stood up against it. There were others who took a hike.
60.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

61.speaker: BROKAW:
61.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

62.speaker: OBAMA:
62.text: Well, Oliver, first, let me tell you what's in the rescue package for you. Right now, the credit markets are frozen up and what that means, as a practical matter, is that small businesses and some large businesses just can't get loans.
62.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

63.speaker: OBAMA:
63.text: If they can't get a loan, that means that they can't make payroll. If they can't make payroll, then they may end up having to shut their doors and lay people off.
63.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

64.speaker: OBAMA:
64.text: And if you imagine just one company trying to deal with that, now imagine a million companies all across the country.
64.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

65.speaker: OBAMA:
65.text: So it could end up having an adverse effect on everybody, and that's why we had to take action. But we shouldn't have been there in the first place.
65.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

66.speaker: OBAMA:
66.text: Now, I've got to correct a little bit of Senator McCain's history, not surprisingly. Let's, first of all, understand that the biggest problem in this whole process was the deregulation of the financial system. Senator McCain, as recently as March, bragged about the fact that he is a deregulator. On the other hand, two years ago, I said that we've got a sub-prime lending crisis that has to be dealt with.
66.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

67.speaker: OBAMA:
67.text: I wrote to Secretary Paulson, I wrote to Federal Reserve Chairman Bernanke, and told them this is something we have to deal with, and nobody did anything about it.
67.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

68.speaker: OBAMA:
68.text: A year ago, I went to Wall Street and said we've got to reregulate, and nothing happened.
68.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

69.speaker: OBAMA:
69.text: And Senator McCain during that period said that we should keep on deregulating because that's how the free enterprise system works.
69.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

70.speaker: OBAMA:
70.text: Now, with respect to Fannie Mae, what Senator McCain didn't mention is the fact that this bill that he talked about wasn't his own bill. He jumped on it a year after it had been introduced and it never got passed.
70.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

71.speaker: OBAMA:
71.text: And I never promoted Fannie Mae. In fact, Senator McCain's campaign chairman's firm was a lobbyist on behalf of Fannie Mae, not me.
71.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

72.speaker: OBAMA:
72.text: So -- but, look, you're not interested in hearing politicians pointing fingers. What you're interested in is trying to figure out, how is this going to impact you?
72.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

73.speaker: OBAMA:
73.text: This is not the end of the process; this is the beginning of the process. And that's why it's going to be so important for us to work with homeowners to make sure that they can stay in their homes.
73.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

74.speaker: OBAMA:
74.text: The secretary already has the power to do that in the rescue package, but it hasn't been exercised yet. And the next president has to make sure that the next Treasury secretary is thinking about how to strengthen you as a home buyer, you as a homeowner, and not simply think about bailing out banks on Wall Street.
74.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

75.speaker: BROKAW:
75.text: Senator Obama, time for a discussion. I'm going to begin with you. Are you saying to Mr. Clark and to the other members of the American television audience that the American economy is going to get much worse before it gets better and they ought to be prepared for that?
75.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

76.speaker: OBAMA:
76.text: No, I am confident about the American economy. But we are going to have to have some leadership from Washington that not only sets out much better regulations for the financial system.
76.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

77.speaker: OBAMA:
77.text: The problem is we still have a archaic, 20th-century regulatory system for 21st-century financial markets. We're going to have to coordinate with other countries to make sure that whatever actions we take work.
77.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

78.speaker: OBAMA:
78.text: But most importantly, we're going to have to help ordinary families be able to stay in their homes, make sure that they can pay their bills, deal with critical issues like health care and energy, and we're going to have to change the culture in Washington so that lobbyists and special interests aren't driving the process and your voices aren't being drowned out.
78.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

79.speaker: BROKAW:
79.text: Senator McCain, in all candor, do you think the economy is going to get worse before it gets better?
79.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

80.speaker: MCCAIN:
80.text: I think it depends on what we do. I think if we act effectively, if we stabilize the housing market -- which I believe we can, if we go out and buy up these bad loans, so that people can have a new mortgage at the new value of their home -- I think if we get rid of the cronyism and special interest influence in Washington so we can act more effectively.
80.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

81.speaker: MCCAIN:
81.text: My friend, I'd like you to see the letter that a group of senators and I wrote warning exactly of this crisis. Senator Obama's name was not on that letter.
81.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

82.speaker: MCCAIN:
82.text: The point is -- the point is that we can fix our economy. Americans' workers are the best in the world. They're the fundamental aspect of America's economy.
82.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

83.speaker: MCCAIN:
83.text: They're the most innovative. They're the best -- they're most -- have best -- we're the best exporters. We're the best importers. They're most effective. They are the best workers in the world.
83.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

84.speaker: MCCAIN:
84.text: And we've got to give them a chance. They've got -- we've got to give them a chance to do their best again. And they are the innocent bystanders here in what is the biggest financial crisis and challenge of our time. We can do it.
84.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

85.speaker: BROKAW:
85.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

86.speaker: BROKAW:
86.text: We're going to continue over in Section F, as it turns out.
86.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

87.speaker: BROKAW:
87.text: Senator Obama, this is a question from you from Theresa Finch.
87.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

88.speaker: BROKAW:
88.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

89.speaker: QUESTION:
89.text: How can we trust either of you with our money when both parties got -- got us into this global economic crisis?
89.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

90.speaker: OBAMA:
90.text: Well, look, I understand your frustration and your cynicism, because while you've been carrying out your responsibilities -- most of the people here, you've got a family budget. If less money is coming in, you end up making cuts. Maybe you don't go out to dinner as much. Maybe you put off buying a new car.
90.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

91.speaker: OBAMA:
91.text: That's not what happens in Washington. And you're right. There is a lot of blame to go around.
91.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

92.speaker: OBAMA:
92.text: But I think it's important just to remember a little bit of history. When George Bush came into office, we had surpluses. And now we have half-a-trillion-dollar deficit annually.
92.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

93.speaker: OBAMA:
93.text: When George Bush came into office, our debt -- national debt was around $5 trillion. It's now over $10 trillion. We've almost doubled it. And so while it's true that nobody's completely innocent here, we have had over the last eight years the biggest increases in deficit spending and national debt in our history. And Senator McCain voted for four out of five of those George Bush budgets.
93.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

94.speaker: OBAMA:
94.text: So here's what I would do. I'm going to spend some money on the key issues that we've got to work on.
94.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

95.speaker: OBAMA:
95.text: You know, you may have seen your health care premiums go up. We've got to reform health care to help you and your budget.
95.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

96.speaker: OBAMA:
96.text: We are going to have to deal with energy because we can't keep on borrowing from the Chinese and sending money to Saudi Arabia. We are mortgaging our children's future. We've got to have a different energy plan.
96.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

97.speaker: OBAMA:
97.text: We've got to invest in college affordability. So we're going to have to make some investments, but we've also got to make spending cuts. And what I've proposed, you'll hear Senator McCain say, well, he's proposing a whole bunch of new spending, but actually I'm cutting more than I'm spending so that it will be a net spending cut.
97.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

98.speaker: OBAMA:
98.text: The key is whether or not we've got priorities that are working for you as opposed to those who have been dictating the policy in Washington lately, and that's mostly lobbyists and special interests. We've got to put an end to that.
98.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

99.speaker: BROKAW:
99.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

100.speaker: MCCAIN:
100.text: Well, Theresa, thank you. And I can see why you feel that cynicism and mistrust, because the system in Washington is broken. And I have been a consistent reformer.
100.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

101.speaker: MCCAIN:
101.text: I have advocated and taken on the special interests, whether they be the big money people by reaching across the aisle and working with Senator Feingold on campaign finance reform, whether it being a variety of other issues, working with Senator Lieberman on trying to address climate change.
101.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

102.speaker: MCCAIN:
102.text: I have a clear record of bipartisanship. The situation today cries out for bipartisanship. Senator Obama has never taken on his leaders of his party on a single issue. And we need to reform.
102.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

103.speaker: MCCAIN:
103.text: And so let's look at our records as well as our rhetoric. That's really part of your mistrust here. And now I suggest that maybe you go to some of these organizations that are the watchdogs of what we do, like the Citizens Against Government Waste or the National Taxpayers Union or these other organizations that watch us all the time.
103.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

104.speaker: MCCAIN:
104.text: I don't expect you to watch every vote. And you know what you'll find? This is the most liberal big-spending record in the United States Senate. I have fought against excessive spending and outrages. I have fought to reduce the earmarks and eliminate them. Do you know that Senator Obama has voted for -- is proposing $860 billion of new spending now? New spending. Do you know that he voted for every increase in spending that I saw come across the floor of the United States Senate while we were working to eliminate these pork barrel earmarks?
104.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

105.speaker: MCCAIN:
105.text: He voted for nearly a billion dollars in pork barrel earmark projects, including, by the way, $3 million for an overhead projector at a planetarium in Chicago, Illinois. My friends, do we need to spend that kind of money?
105.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

106.speaker: MCCAIN:
106.text: I think you have to look at my record and you have to look at his. Then you have to look at our proposals for our economy, not $860 billion in new spending, but for the kinds of reforms that keep people in their jobs, get middle-income Americans working again, and getting our economy moving again.
106.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

107.speaker: MCCAIN:
107.text: You're going to be examining our proposals tonight and in the future, and energy independence is a way to do that, is one of them. And drilling offshore and nuclear power are two vital elements of that. And I've been supporting those and I know how to fix this economy, and eliminate our dependence on foreign oil, and stop sending $700 billion a year overseas.
107.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

108.speaker: BROKAW:
108.text: We've run out of time. We have this one-minute discussion period going on here.
108.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

109.speaker: BROKAW:
109.text: There are new economic realities out there that everyone in this hall and across this country understands that there are going to have to be some choices made. Health policies, energy policies, and entitlement reform, what are going to be your priorities in what order? Which of those will be your highest priority your first year in office and which will follow in sequence?
109.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

110.speaker: BROKAW:
110.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

111.speaker: MCCAIN:
111.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

112.speaker: BROKAW:
112.text: The three -- health care, energy, and entitlement reform: Social Security and Medicare. In what order would you put them in terms of priorities?
112.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

113.speaker: MCCAIN:
113.text: I think you can work on all three at once, Tom. I think it's very important that reform our entitlement programs.
113.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

114.speaker: MCCAIN:
114.text: My friends, we are not going to be able to provide the same benefit for present-day workers that we are going -- that present-day retirees have today. We're going to have to sit down across the table, Republican and Democrat, as we did in 1983 between Ronald Reagan and Tip O'Neill.
114.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

115.speaker: MCCAIN:
115.text: I know how to do that. I have a clear record of reaching across the aisle, whether it be Joe Lieberman or Russ Feingold or Ted Kennedy or others. That's my clear record.
115.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

116.speaker: MCCAIN:
116.text: We can work on nuclear power plants. Build a whole bunch of them, create millions of new jobs. We have to have all of the above, alternative fuels, wind, tide, solar, natural gas, clean coal technology. All of these things we can do as Americans and we can take on this mission and we can overcome it.
116.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

117.speaker: MCCAIN:
117.text: My friends, some of this $700 billion ends up in the hands of terrorist organizations.
117.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

118.speaker: MCCAIN:
118.text: As far as health care is concerned, obviously, everyone is struggling to make sure that they can afford their premiums and that they can have affordable and available health care. That's the next issue.
118.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

119.speaker: MCCAIN:
119.text: But we can do them all at once. There's no -- and we have to do them all at once. All three you mentioned are compelling national security requirements.
119.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

120.speaker: BROKAW:
120.text: I'm trying to play by the rules that you all established. One minute for discussion.
120.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

121.speaker: BROKAW:
121.text: Senator Obama, if you would give us your list of priorities, there are some real questions about whether everything can be done at once.
121.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

122.speaker: OBAMA:
122.text: We're going to have to prioritize, just like a family has to prioritize. Now, I've listed the things that I think have to be at the top of the list.
122.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

123.speaker: OBAMA:
123.text: Energy we have to deal with today, because you're paying $3.80 here in Nashville for gasoline, and it could go up. And it's a strain on your family budget, but it's also bad for our national security, because countries like Russia and Venezuela and, you know, in some cases, countries like Iran, are benefiting from higher oil prices.
123.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

124.speaker: OBAMA:
124.text: So we've got to deal with that right away. That's why I've called for an investment of $15 billion a year over 10 years. Our goal should be, in 10 year's time, we are free of dependence on Middle Eastern oil.
124.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

125.speaker: OBAMA:
125.text: And we can do it. Now, when JFK said we're going to the Moon in 10 years, nobody was sure how to do it, but we understood that, if the American people make a decision to do something, it gets done. So that would be priority number one.
125.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

126.speaker: OBAMA:
126.text: Health care is priority number two, because that broken health care system is bad not only for families, but it's making our businesses less competitive.
126.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

127.speaker: OBAMA:
127.text: And, number three, we've got to deal with education so that our young people are competitive in a global economy.
127.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

128.speaker: OBAMA:
128.text: But just one point I want to make, Tom. Senator McCain mentioned looking at our records. We do need to look at our records.
128.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

129.speaker: OBAMA:
129.text: Senator McCain likes to talk about earmarks a lot. And that's important. I want to go line by line through every item in the federal budget and eliminate programs that don't work and make sure that those that do work, work better and cheaper.
129.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

130.speaker: OBAMA:
130.text: But understand this: We also have to look at where some of our tax revenues are going. So when Senator McCain proposes a $300 billion tax cut, a continuation not only of the Bush tax cuts, but an additional $200 billion that he's going to give to big corporations, including big oil companies, $4 billion worth, that's money out of the system.
130.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

131.speaker: OBAMA:
131.text: And so we've got to prioritize both our spending side and our tax policies to make sure that they're working for you. That's what I'm going to do as president of the United States.
131.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

132.speaker: BROKAW:
132.text: All right, gentlemen, I want to just remind you one more time about time. We're going to have a larger deficit than the federal government does if we don't get this under control here before too long.
132.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

133.speaker: BROKAW:
133.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

134.speaker: BROKAW:
134.text: Senator McCain, for you, we have our first question from the Internet tonight. A child of the Depression, 78-year-old Fiora from Chicago.
134.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

135.speaker: BROKAW:
135.text: Since World War II, we have never been asked to sacrifice anything to help our country, except the blood of our heroic men and women. As president, what sacrifices -- sacrifices will you ask every American to make to help restore the American dream and to get out of the economic morass that we're now in?
135.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

136.speaker: MCCAIN:
136.text: Well, Fiora, I'm going to ask the American people to understand that there are some programs that we may have to eliminate.
136.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

137.speaker: MCCAIN:
137.text: I first proposed a long time ago that we would have to examine every agency and every bureaucracy of government. And we're going to have to eliminate those that aren't working.
137.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

138.speaker: MCCAIN:
138.text: I know a lot of them that aren't working. One of them is in defense spending, because I've taken on some of the defense contractors. I saved the taxpayers $6.8 billion in a deal for an Air Force tanker that was done in a corrupt fashion.
138.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

139.speaker: MCCAIN:
139.text: I believe that we have to eliminate the earmarks. And sometimes those projects, not -- not the overhead projector that Senator Obama asked for, but some of them that are really good projects, will have -- will have to be eliminated, as well.
139.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

140.speaker: MCCAIN:
140.text: And they'll have to undergo the same scrutiny that all projects should in competition with others.
140.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

141.speaker: MCCAIN:
141.text: So we're going to have to tell the American people that spending is going to have to be cut in America. And I recommend a spending freeze that -- except for defense, Veterans Affairs, and some other vital programs, we'll just have to have across-the-board freeze.
141.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

142.speaker: MCCAIN:
142.text: And some of those programs may not grow as much as we would like for them to, but we can establish priorities with full transparency, with full knowledge of the American people, and full consultation, not done behind closed doors and shoving earmarks in the middle of the night into programs that we don't even -- sometimes we don't even know about until months later.
142.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

143.speaker: MCCAIN:
143.text: And, by the way, I want to go back a second.
143.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

144.speaker: MCCAIN:
144.text: Look, we can attack health care and energy at the same time. We're not -- we're not -- we're not rifle shots here. We are Americans. We can, with the participation of all Americans, work together and solve these problems together.
144.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

145.speaker: MCCAIN:
145.text: Frankly, I'm not going to tell that person without health insurance that, "I'm sorry, you'll have to wait." I'm going to tell you Americans we'll get to work right away and we'll get to work together, and we can get them all done, because that's what America has been doing.
145.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

146.speaker: BROKAW:
146.text: Senator McCain, thank you very much.
146.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

147.speaker: BROKAW:
147.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

148.speaker: OBAMA:
148.text: You know, a lot of you remember the tragedy of 9/11 and where you were on that day and, you know, how all of the country was ready to come together and make enormous changes to make us not only safer, but to make us a better country and a more unified country.
148.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

149.speaker: OBAMA:
149.text: And President Bush did some smart things at the outset, but one of the opportunities that was missed was, when he spoke to the American people, he said, "Go out and shop."
149.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

150.speaker: OBAMA:
150.text: That wasn't the kind of call to service that I think the American people were looking for.
150.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

151.speaker: OBAMA:
151.text: And so it's important to understand that the -- I think the American people are hungry for the kind of leadership that is going to tackle these problems not just in government, but outside of government.
151.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

152.speaker: OBAMA:
152.text: And let's take the example of energy, which we already spoke about. There is going to be the need for each and every one of us to start thinking about how we use energy.
152.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

153.speaker: OBAMA:
153.text: I believe in the need for increased oil production. We're going to have to explore new ways to get more oil, and that includes offshore drilling. It includes telling the oil companies, that currently have 68 million acres that they're not using, that either you use them or you lose them.
153.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

154.speaker: OBAMA:
154.text: We're going to have to develop clean coal technology and safe ways to store nuclear energy.
154.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

155.speaker: OBAMA:
155.text: But each and every one of us can start thinking about how can we save energy in our homes, in our buildings. And one of the things I want to do is make sure that we're providing incentives so that you can buy a fuel efficient car that's made right here in the United States of America, not in Japan or South Korea, making sure that you are able to weatherize your home or make your business more fuel efficient.
155.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

156.speaker: OBAMA:
156.text: And that's going to require effort from each and every one of us.
156.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

157.speaker: OBAMA:
157.text: And the last point I just want to make. I think the young people of America are especially interested in how they can serve, and that's one of the reasons why I'm interested in doubling the Peace Corps, making sure that we are creating a volunteer corps all across this country that can be involved in their community, involved in military service, so that military families and our troops are not the only ones bearing the burden of renewing America.
157.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

158.speaker: OBAMA:
158.text: That's something that all of us have to be involved with and that requires some leadership from Washington.
158.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

159.speaker: BROKAW:
159.text: Senator Obama, as we begin, very quickly, our discussion period, President Bush, you'll remember, last summer, said that "Wall Street got drunk."
159.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

160.speaker: BROKAW:
160.text: A lot of people now look back and think the federal government got drunk and, in fact, the American consumers got drunk.
160.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

161.speaker: BROKAW:
161.text: How would you, as president, try to break those bad habits of too much debt and too much easy credit, specifically, across the board, for this country, not just at the federal level, but as a model for the rest of the country, as well?
161.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

162.speaker: OBAMA:
162.text: Well, I think it starts with Washington. We've got to show that we've got good habits, because if we're running up trillion dollar debts that we're passing on to the next generation, then a lot of people are going to think, "Well, you know what? There's easy money out there."
162.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

163.speaker: OBAMA:
163.text: It means -- and I have to, again, repeat this. It means looking at the spending side, but also at the revenue side. I mean, Senator McCain has been talking tough about earmarks, and that's good, but earmarks account for about $18 billion of our budget.
163.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

164.speaker: OBAMA:
164.text: Now, when Senator McCain is proposing tax cuts that would give the average Fortune 500 CEO an additional $700,000 in tax cuts, that's not sharing a burden.
164.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

165.speaker: OBAMA:
165.text: And so part of the problem, I think, for a lot of people who are listening here tonight is they don't feel as if they are sharing the burden with other folks.
165.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

166.speaker: OBAMA:
166.text: I mean, you know, it's tough to ask a teacher who's making $30,000 or $35,000 a year to tighten her belt when people who are making much more than her are living pretty high on the hog.
166.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

167.speaker: OBAMA:
167.text: And that's why I think it's important for the president to set a tone that says all of us are going to contribute, all of us are going to make sacrifices, and it means that, yes, we may have to cut some spending, although I disagree with Senator McCain about an across-the- board freeze.
167.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

168.speaker: OBAMA:
168.text: That's an example of an unfair burden sharing. That's using a hatchet to cut the federal budget.
168.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

169.speaker: OBAMA:
169.text: I want to use a scalpel so that people who need help are getting help and those of us, like myself and Senator McCain, who don't need help, aren't getting it.
169.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

170.speaker: OBAMA:
170.text: That's how we make sure that everybody is willing to make a few sacrifices.
170.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

171.speaker: BROKAW:
171.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

172.speaker: MCCAIN:
172.text: Well, you know, nailing down Senator Obama's various tax proposals is like nailing Jell-O to the wall. There has been five or six of them and if you wait long enough, there will probably be another one.
172.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

173.speaker: MCCAIN:
173.text: But he wants to raise taxes. My friends, the last president to raise taxes during tough economic times was Herbert Hoover, and he practiced protectionism as well, which I'm sure we'll get to at some point.
173.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

174.speaker: MCCAIN:
174.text: You know, last year up to this time, we've lost 700,000 jobs in America. The only bright spot is that over 300,000 jobs have been created by small businesses. Senator Obama's secret that you don't know is that his tax increases will increase taxes on 50 percent of small business revenue.
174.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

175.speaker: MCCAIN:
175.text: Small businesses across America will have to cut jobs and will have their taxes increase and won't be able to hire because of Senator Obama's tax policies. You know, he said some time ago, he said he would forgo his tax increases if the economy was bad.
175.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

176.speaker: MCCAIN:
176.text: I've got some news, Senator Obama, the news is bad. So let's not raise anybody's taxes, my friends, and make it be very clear to you I am not in favor of tax cuts for the wealthy. I am in favor of leaving the tax rates alone and reducing the tax burden on middle-income Americans by doubling your tax exemption for every child from $3,500 to $7,000.
176.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

177.speaker: MCCAIN:
177.text: To giving every American a $5,000 refundable tax credit and go out and get the health insurance you want rather than mandates and fines for small businesses, as Senator Obama's plan calls for. And let's create jobs and let's get our economy going again. And let's not raise anybody's taxes.
177.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

178.speaker: BROKAW:
178.text: Senator Obama, we have another question from the Internet.
178.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

179.speaker: OBAMA:
179.text: Tom, can I respond to this briefly? Because...
179.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

180.speaker: BROKAW:
180.text: Well, look, guys, the rules were established by the two campaigns, we worked very hard on this. This will address, I think, the next question.
180.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

181.speaker: OBAMA:
181.text: The tax issue, because I think it's very important. Go ahead.
181.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

182.speaker: BROKAW:
182.text: There are lots of issues that we are going to be dealing with here tonight. And we have a question from Langdon in Ballston Spa, New York, and that's about huge unfunded obligations for Social Security, Medicare, and other entitlement programs that will soon eat up all of the revenue that's in place and then go into a deficit position.
182.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

183.speaker: BROKAW:
183.text: Since the rules are pretty loose here, I'm going to add my own to this one. Instead of having a discussion, let me ask you as a coda to that. Would you give Congress a date certain to reform Social Security and Medicare within two years after you take office? Because in a bipartisan way, everyone agrees, that's a big ticking time bomb that will eat us up maybe even more than the mortgage crisis.
183.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

184.speaker: OBAMA:
184.text: Well, Tom, we're going to have to take on entitlements and I think we've got to do it quickly. We're going to have a lot of work to do, so I can't guarantee that we're going to do it in the next two years, but I'd like to do in the my first term as president.
184.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

185.speaker: OBAMA:
185.text: But I think it's important to understand, we're not going to solve Social Security and Medicare unless we understand the rest of our tax policies. And you know, Senator McCain, I think the "Straight Talk Express" lost a wheel on that one.
185.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

186.speaker: OBAMA:
186.text: So let's be clear about my tax plan and Senator McCain's, because we're not going to be able to deal with entitlements unless we understand the revenues coming in. I want to provide a tax cut for 95 percent of Americans, 95 percent.
186.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

187.speaker: OBAMA:
187.text: If you make less than a quarter of a million dollars a year, you will not see a single dime of your taxes go up. If you make $200,000 a year or less, your taxes will go down.
187.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

188.speaker: OBAMA:
188.text: Now, Senator McCain talks about small businesses. Only a few percent of small businesses make more than $250,000 a year. So the vast majority of small businesses would get a tax cut under my plan.
188.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

189.speaker: OBAMA:
189.text: And we provide a 50 percent tax credit so that they can buy health insurance for their workers, because there are an awful lot of small businesses that I meet across America that want to do right by their workers but they just can't afford it. Some small business owners, a lot of them, can't even afford health insurance for themselves.
189.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

190.speaker: OBAMA:
190.text: Now, in contrast, Senator McCain wants to give a $300 billion tax cut, $200 billion of it to the largest corporations and a hundred thousand of it -- a hundred billion of it going to people like CEOs on Wall Street. He wants to give average Fortune 500 CEO an additional $700,000 in tax cuts. That is not fair. And it doesn't work.
190.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

191.speaker: OBAMA:
191.text: Now, if we get our tax policies right so that they're good for the middle class, if we reverse the policies of the last eight years that got us into this fix in the first place and that Senator McCain supported, then we are going to be in a position to deal with Social Security and deal with Medicare, because we will have a health care plan that actually works for you, reduces spending and costs over the long term, and Social Security that is stable and solvent for all Americans and not just some.
191.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

192.speaker: BROKAW:
192.text: Senator McCain, two years for a reform of entitlement programs?
192.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

193.speaker: MCCAIN:
193.text: Sure. Hey, I'll answer the question. Look -- look, it's not that hard to fix Social Security, Tom. It's just...
193.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

194.speaker: BROKAW:
194.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

195.speaker: MCCAIN:
195.text: ... tough decisions. I want to get to Medicare in a second.
195.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

196.speaker: MCCAIN:
196.text: Social Security is not that tough. We know what the problems are, my friends, and we know what the fixes are. We've got to sit down together across the table. It's been done before.
196.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

197.speaker: MCCAIN:
197.text: I saw it done with our -- our wonderful Ronald Reagan, a conservative from California, and the liberal Democrat Tip O'Neill from Massachusetts. That's what we need more of, and that's what I've done in Washington.
197.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

198.speaker: MCCAIN:
198.text: Senator Obama has never taken on his party leaders on a single major issue. I've taken them on. I'm not too popular sometimes with my own party, much less his.
198.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

199.speaker: MCCAIN:
199.text: So Medicare, it's going to be a little tougher. It's going to be a little tougher because we're talking about very complex and difficult issues.
199.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

200.speaker: MCCAIN:
200.text: My friends, what we have to do with Medicare is have a commission, have the smartest people in America come together, come up with recommendations, and then, like the base-closing commission idea we had, then we should have Congress vote up or down.
200.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

201.speaker: MCCAIN:
201.text: Let's not let them fool with it anymore. There's too much special interests and too many lobbyists working there. So let's have -- and let's have the American people say, "Fix it for us." Now, just back on this -- on this tax, you know, again, it's back to our first question here about rhetoric and record. Senator Obama has voted 94 times to either increase your taxes or against tax cuts. That's his record.
201.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

202.speaker: MCCAIN:
202.text: When he ran for the United States Senate from Illinois, he said he would have a middle-income tax cut. You know he came to the Senate and never once proposed legislation to do that?
202.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

203.speaker: MCCAIN:
203.text: So let's look at our record. I've fought higher taxes. I have fought excess spending. I have fought to reform government.
203.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

204.speaker: MCCAIN:
204.text: Let's look at our records, my friends, and then listen to my vision for the future of America. And we'll get our economy going again. And our best days are ahead of us.
204.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

205.speaker: BROKAW:
205.text: Senator McCain, thank you very much. I'm going to stick by my part of the pact and not ask a follow-up here.
205.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

206.speaker: BROKAW:
206.text: The next question does come from the hall for Senator McCain. It comes from Section C over here, and it's from Ingrid Jackson.
206.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

207.speaker: BROKAW:
207.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

208.speaker: QUESTION:
208.text: Senator McCain, I want to know, we saw that Congress moved pretty fast in the face of an economic crisis. I want to know what you would do within the first two years to make sure that Congress moves fast as far as environmental issues, like climate change and green jobs?
208.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

209.speaker: MCCAIN:
209.text: Well, thank you. Look, we are in tough economic times; we all know that. And let's keep -- never forget the struggle that Americans are in today.
209.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

210.speaker: MCCAIN:
210.text: But when we can -- when we have an issue that we may hand our children and our grandchildren a damaged planet, I have disagreed strongly with the Bush administration on this issue. I traveled all over the world looking at the effects of greenhouse gas emissions, Joe Lieberman and I.
210.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

211.speaker: MCCAIN:
211.text: And I introduced the first legislation, and we forced votes on it. That's the good news, my friends. The bad news is we lost. But we kept the debate going, and we kept this issue to -- to posing to Americans the danger that climate change opposes.
211.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

212.speaker: MCCAIN:
212.text: Now, how -- what's -- what's the best way of fixing it? Nuclear power. Senator Obama says that it has to be safe or disposable or something like that.
212.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

213.speaker: MCCAIN:
213.text: Look, I -- I was on Navy ships that had nuclear power plants. Nuclear power is safe, and it's clean, and it creates hundreds of thousands of jobs.
213.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

214.speaker: MCCAIN:
214.text: And -- and I know that we can reprocess the spent nuclear fuel. The Japanese, the British, the French do it. And we can do it, too. Senator Obama has opposed that. We can move forward, and clean up our climate, and develop green technologies, and alternate -- alternative energies for -- for hybrid, for hydrogen, for battery-powered cars, so that we can clean up our environment and at the same time get our economy going by creating millions of jobs.
214.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

215.speaker: MCCAIN:
215.text: We can do that, we as Americans, because we're the best innovators, we're the best producers, and 95 percent of the people who are our market live outside of the United States of America.
215.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

216.speaker: BROKAW:
216.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

217.speaker: OBAMA:
217.text: This is one of the biggest challenges of our times.
217.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

218.speaker: OBAMA:
218.text: And it is absolutely critical that we understand this is not just a challenge, it's an opportunity, because if we create a new energy economy, we can create five million new jobs, easily, here in the United States.
218.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

219.speaker: OBAMA:
219.text: It can be an engine that drives us into the future the same way the computer was the engine for economic growth over the last couple of decades.
219.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

220.speaker: OBAMA:
220.text: And we can do it, but we're going to have to make an investment. The same way the computer was originally invented by a bunch of government scientists who were trying to figure out, for defense purposes, how to communicate, we've got to understand that this is a national security issue, as well.
220.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

221.speaker: OBAMA:
221.text: And that's why we've got to make some investments and I've called for investments in solar, wind, geothermal. Contrary to what Senator McCain keeps on saying, I favor nuclear power as one component of our overall energy mix.
221.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

222.speaker: OBAMA:
222.text: But this is another example where I think it is important to look at the record. Senator McCain and I actually agree on something. He said a while back that the big problem with energy is that for 30 years, politicians in Washington haven't done anything.
222.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

223.speaker: OBAMA:
223.text: What Senator McCain doesn't mention is he's been there 26 of them. And during that time, he voted 23 times against alternative fuels, 23 times.
223.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

224.speaker: OBAMA:
224.text: So it's easy to talk about this stuff during a campaign, but it's important for us to understand that it requires a sustained effort from the next president.
224.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

225.speaker: OBAMA:
225.text: One last point I want to make on energy. Senator McCain talks a lot about drilling, and that's important, but we have three percent of the world's oil reserves and we use 25 percent of the world's oil.
225.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

226.speaker: OBAMA:
226.text: So what that means is that we can't simply drill our way out of the problem. And we're not going to be able to deal with the climate crisis if our only solution is to use more fossil fuels that create global warming.
226.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

227.speaker: OBAMA:
227.text: We're going to have to come up with alternatives, and that means that the United States government is working with the private sector to fund the kind of innovation that we can then export to countries like China that also need energy and are setting up one coal power plant a week.
227.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

228.speaker: OBAMA:
228.text: We've got to make sure that we're giving them the energy that they need or helping them to create the energy that they need.
228.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

229.speaker: BROKAW:
229.text: Gentlemen, you may not have noticed, but we have lights around here. They have red and green and yellow and they are to signal...
229.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

230.speaker: OBAMA:
230.text: I'm just trying to keep up with John.
230.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

231.speaker: MCCAIN:
231.text: Tom, wave like that and I'll look at you.
231.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

232.speaker: BROKAW:
232.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

233.speaker: BROKAW:
233.text: Here's a follow-up to that, one-minute discussion. It's a simple question.
233.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

234.speaker: MCCAIN:
234.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

235.speaker: BROKAW:
235.text: Should we fund a Manhattan-like project that develops a nuclear bomb to deal with global energy and alternative energy or should we fund 100,000 garages across America, the kind of industry and innovation that developed Silicon Valley?
235.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

236.speaker: MCCAIN:
236.text: I think pure research and development investment on the part of the United States government is certainly appropriate. I think once it gets into productive stages, that we ought to, obviously, turn it over to the private sector.
236.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

237.speaker: MCCAIN:
237.text: By the way, my friends, I know you grow a little weary with this back-and-forth. It was an energy bill on the floor of the Senate loaded down with goodies, billions for the oil companies, and it was sponsored by Bush and Cheney.
237.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

238.speaker: MCCAIN:
238.text: You know who voted for it? You might never know. That one. You know who voted against it? Me. I have fought time after time against these pork barrel -- these bills that come to the floor and they have all kinds of goodies and all kinds of things in them for everybody and they buy off the votes.
238.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

239.speaker: MCCAIN:
239.text: I vote against them, my friends. I vote against them. But the point is, also, on oil drilling, oil drilling offshore now is vital so that we can bridge the gap. We can bridge the gap between imported oil, which is a national security issue, as well as any other, and it will reduce the price of a barrel of oil, because when people know there's a greater supply, then the cost of that will go down.
239.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

240.speaker: MCCAIN:
240.text: That's fundamental economics. We've got to drill offshore, my friends, and we've got to do it now, and we can do it.
240.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

241.speaker: MCCAIN:
241.text: And as far as nuclear power is concerned, again, look at the record. Senator Obama has approved storage and reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel.
241.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

242.speaker: MCCAIN:
242.text: And I'll stop, Tom, and you didn't even wave. Thanks.
242.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

243.speaker: BROKAW:
243.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

244.speaker: BROKAW:
244.text: Next question for you, Senator Obama, and it comes from the E section over here and it's from Lindsey Trellow.
244.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

245.speaker: BROKAW:
245.title: Presidential Candidates Debates: Presidential Debate at Belmont University in Nashville, Tennessee

246.speaker: QUESTION:
